STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 30, 2023
Charles Benjamin Rose
ST JOSEPH COUNTY DHHS
692 E MAIN ST,
CENTREVILLE, MI, 49032-9301
RE: License#: CP750201427
Dear Charles Benjamin Rose:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 626-6/29/2023 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP750201427
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Charles Rose
Name of Agency: ST JOSEPH COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 692 E MAIN ST
CENTREVILLE, MI 49032-9301
Agency Telephone #: 2694671200
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1991
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months
before placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
1 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placement contained documentation that
an initial dental exam was not completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 9/1/2022, CAP Approval 9/21/2022
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING

FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement
or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
3 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation
that all required FTM’s were held timely. Additionally, all 3 were misssing FTM
paperwork for FTM’s documented to have been held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/1/2022, CAP Approval 9/21/2022
F OM 722-06H C ASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face
contact in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If
there is more than one caregiver, such as a primary
and secondary caregiver, the caseworker must have a

face-to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the
home at least once each quarter.
3 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation
that the secondary caregiver in the youth's foster home were present for monthly
home vists at least quarterly.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/1/2022, CAP Approval 9/21/2022
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care
are placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan to review, and I will have the opportunity to
express my disagreement with the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s

and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report
date.
6 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain all required
signatures obtained timely on all PATPs. The missing/late signatures represented
10 of 15 PATPs reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/1/2022, CAP Approval 9/21/2022
F OM 801-03 M EDICAL PASSPORT
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following: • Foster care
provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care. The actual
date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management
record. Note: Foster care provider includes foster
homes, shelter, adult foster home, fictive kin, relative
placements, detention, and residential facilities.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Each caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the
medical passport verifying that they have sought and
obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification. Non-offending parent,

subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. Note: Non-offending parent with custody of
the child is not considered a foster parent placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for
treatment or services prior to or at the first scheduled
appointment while the foster care case is open,
regardless of placement. Subsequent medical
passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults: Upon initial independent
living placement (youth aged 16 and over). Upon
exiting the foster care system (young adults aged 18
and older)
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed
parties is documented in the electronic case
management record by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile
section.
5 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain all required
updates and/or signatures on medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/1/2022, CAP Approval 9/21/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• - Multiple documents were located in incorrect places within the electronic
file. Review upload requirements with staff incorrectly uploading to ensure
that all documents can be located/tracked properly for compliance.
• - When reviewing 4004s be sure to check the CWLM data to ensure it
accurately reflects the actions taken during the evaluation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• - To ensure that documents are all in the case record as required, supervisors
could implement a review of electronic case records periodically, such as
during supervision. This will help reduce the number of documents missing
from case records.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The one report addressing maltreatment was reviewed and found to be
completed thoroughly and accurately.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The one report addressing maltreatment was reviewed and found to be
completed thoroughly and accurately.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was submitted in response to the 9/1/2022 interim
licensing inspection and was approved on 9/21/2022. That CAP addressed 14
citations, nine of which were not cited as violations during this inspection. The
remaining five were repeated during this inspection. Three of the five repeated
citations; FTMs, PATP signatures, and Medical Passports have all been repeated
during the past two inspections and will require additional corrective action
planning to address the repeated nature and prevalence of the citations. Of the
remaining two citations, Case Contacts was violated in half of the cases reviewed
and dental examinations was an isolated incident during this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator identified several areas of policy and data entry
requirements that have led to difficulty in maintaining compliance due the timely
nature of duplicating work tasks. Additionally, there have been some case
transfers due to staff medical leave and two current case management vacancies
which has resulted in some difficulty maintaining consistent compliance with all
case management requirements.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
One staff interviewed expressed several concerns related to the CWLM system,
BSC, and new foster home rule implementation. One staff interviewed expressed
concerns of feeling there is a focus on meeting deadlines and maintaining specific
statistics as opposed to providing quality services. One staff member reported no
concerns. All three stated they feel supported and encouraged in their daily tasks
by their peers and direct supervisors.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to perform job
responsibilities. Case records and physical CHRI are stored in a method that
prevents unauthorized access through the use of locked cabinets, locked storage
shelves, and a locked storage room in which files are stored in closeable cabinets

in which no unauthorized personnel are allowed to enter unless escorted by an
authorized staff member who will ensure the file cabinets are closed and not
accessed while unauthorized personnel are present.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No Safety Concerns Identified
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
June 29, 2023
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 30, 2023
____________________________________ _
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
